preface.title: Preface
preface.para: This guide provides information on upgrades for core OpenAM services, policy agents, and components.

section.title: Who Should Use this Guide
section.para: This guide is for anyone who needs to upgrade an OpenAM deployment. This guide defines the different release types and the steps to complete an upgrade. It is likely you will need to periodically use this guide to keep your OpenAM instance current.

itemizedlist.para: This guide is organized as follows:

listitem.para: Introduction to Upgrades defines the three version numbers and how they indicate what type of release you are considering. It also provides basic information about migrating legacy deployments and upgrading OpenAM components, like tools and policy agents.
Upgrading an OpenAM Deployment includes the procedure to upgrade your OpenAM instance and an example to illustrate the procedure.
Migrating from a Legacy OpenAM Deployment describes legacy deployments of OpenAM and procedures on how to upgrade to a more current version.

Upgrading OpenAM Components includes the procedure to update policy agents and an example of updating the Apache 2.2 web agent, to upgrade the tools and examples, and to upgrade Distributed Authentication services with an example.

Best Practices for Upgrading Your OpenAM Deployment gives general advice and instructions for backing up your deployment prior to upgrading, applying your current customizations to the new OpenAM .war, and rolling back OpenAM core and configuration store. It does not cover information for instances that have a dependency on an external replicated directory server. Restoration of earlier policy agents is included in the appendix.
Troubleshooting the Upgrade Process provides information on ways to troubleshoot issues you may encounter.

section.para: You do not need to be an OpenAM wizard to learn something from this guide, though a background in access management and maintaining web application software can help. You do need some background in managing services on your operating systems and in your application servers. You can nevertheless get started with this guide, and then learn more as you go.
